title: Council hopes scary ‘Frankenpigeon’ posters will make people stop feeding birds
text:
Do not feed pigeons or this ‘Frankenpigeon’ will find you and hurt you (Picture: geograph/council)

If sky rats do not scare you then nothing will.

Authorities in Aylesbury are hoping posters of a ‘Frankenpigeon’ (a pigeon with a rat’s head) will convince people to stop feeding birds in the town centre.

The image of the made up monster bird has been circulated on noticeboards and leaflets, along with reasons why leaving food is bad.

The Aylesbury Town Centre Partnership argued the pigeon population would increase and not be sustainable as a result, Bucks Herald reported.

It claimed left over munchies would become a new source of food for rats and therefore feeding the birds meant you were feeding the rodents as well.

It also argued the increased pigeon droppings would be very corrosive and cause significant damage to buildings and street furniture.

The poster says if you feed pigeons you are also feeding rats (Picture: Aylesbury Vale Council)

The leaflet said white bread was actually unhealthy for pigeons and people should use their leftover stale bread to make ‘bread crumbs, croutons, or delicious bread pudding.’

The brochure also suggested recycling the bread at council facilities to produce methane to generate energy and fertilizer.

Aylesbury town centre (Picture: geograph)

Aylesbury Vale District Council (AVDC) cabinet member for civic amenities councillor Julie Ward said: ‘We are working hard with local business to ensure they dispose of waste responsibly and we provide rodent proof waste bins across the town centre that the public can use to dispose of litter.

‘Our street cleansing teams work hard to ensure that Aylesbury town centre is an attractive and clean environment for residents, shoppers and other visitors – but we need the public to play its part and help us in this endeavour’.

Anyone who doesn’t follow the advice will be stopped and shown the image of the ‘Frankenpigeon’ within the leaflet.

That should really be enough to make them change their ways but we will have to wait and see if it makes a difference.
